Definition: [μάρμαρος] from μαρμαίρω (to glisten); marble (as sparkling white)
[Μάρκος] of Latin origin; Marcus, a Christian
[μαραίνω] of uncertain affinity; to extinguish (as fire), i.e. (figuratively and passively) to pass away
[μαντεύομαι] from a derivative of {{g3105}} (meaning a prophet, as supposed to rave through inspiration); to divine, i.e. utter spells (under pretense of foretelling
[μάννα] of Hebrew origin ({{h4478}}); manna (i.e. man), an edible gum
[μανία] from {{g3105}}; craziness
[Μαρία]   or Μαριάμof Hebrew origin ({{h4813}}); Maria or Mariam (i.e. Mirjam), the name of six Christian females
[Μάρθα] probably of Chaldee origin (meaning mistress); Martha, a Christian woman
[μαργαρίτης] from μάργαρος (a pearl-oyster); a pearl
[μαρὰν ἀθά] of Chaldee origin (meaning our Lord has come); maranatha, i.e. an exclamation of the approaching divine judgment
[Μάλχος] of Hebrew origin ({{h4429}}); Malchus, an Israelite
[μάμμη] of natural origin ("mammy"); a grandmother
[μαμμωνᾶς] of Chaldee origin (confidence, i.e. wealth, personified); mammonas, i.e. avarice (deified)
[Μαναήν] of uncertain origin; Manaën, a Christian
[μαλακός] of uncertain affinity; soft, i.e. fine (clothing); figuratively, a catamite
[Μαλελεήλ] of Hebrew origin ({{h4111}}); Maleleel (i.e. Mahalalel), an antediluvian
[μάλιστα] neuter plural of the superlative of an apparently primary adverb μάλα (very); (adverbially) most (in the greatest degree) or particularly
[μᾶλλον] neuter of the comparative of the same as {{g3122}}; (adverbially) more (in a greater degree)) or rather
[Μανασσῆς] of Hebrew origin ({{h4519}}); Mannasses (i.e. Menashsheh), an Israelite
[μανθάνω] prolongation from a primary verb, another form of which, μαθέω, is used as an alternate in certain tenses; to learn (in any way)
[ματαιολόγος] from {{g3152}} and {{g3004}}; an idle (i.e. senseless or mischievous) talker, i.e. a wrangler
[ματαιολογία] from {{g3151}}; random talk, i.e. babble
[ματαιότης] from {{g3152}}; inutility; figuratively, transientness; morally, depravity
[μάταιος] from the base of {{g3155}}; empty, i.e. (literally) profitless, or (specially), an idol
[μάτην] accusative case of a derivative of the base of {{g3145}} (through the idea of tentative manipulation, i.e. unsuccessful search, or else of punishment); folly, i.e. (adverbially) to no purpose
[ματαιόω] from {{g3152}}; to render (passively, become) foolish, i.e. (morally) wicked or (specially), idolatrous
[Ματθάν] of Hebrew origin ({{h4977}}); Matthan (i.e. Mattan), an Israelite
[Ματθαῖος] a shorter form of {{g3161}}; Matthæus (i.e. Matthitjah), an Israelite and a Christian
[Ματθίας] apparently a shortened form of {{g3161}}; Matthias (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite
[Ματθάτ] probably a shortened form of {{g3161}}; Matthat (i.e. Mattithjah), the name of two Israelites
[μαρτύριον] neuter of a presumed derivative of {{g3144}}; something evidential, i.e. (genitive case) evidence given or (specially), the Decalogue (in the sacred Tabernacle)
[μαρτύρομαι] middle voice from {{g3144}}; to be adduced as a witness, i.e. (figuratively) to obtest (in affirmation or exhortation)
[μαρτυρέω] from {{g3144}}; to be a witness, i.e. testify (literally or figuratively)
[μαρτυρία] from {{g3144}}; evidence given (judicially or genitive case)
[μαστιγόω] from {{g3148}}; to flog (literally or figuratively)
[μαστίζω] from {{g3149}}; to whip (literally)
[μάρτυς] of uncertain affinity; a witness (literally (judicially) or figuratively (genitive case)); by analogy, a "martyr"
[μασσάομαι] from a primary μάσσω (to handle or squeeze); to chew
[μάστιξ] probably from the base of {{g3145}} (through the idea of contact); a whip (literally, the Roman flagellum for criminals; figuratively, a disease)
[μαστός] from the base of {{g3145}}; a (properly, female) breast (as if kneaded up)
[μεμβράνα] of Latin origin ("membrane"); a (written) sheep-skin
[μεθίστημι] , or (1 Cor. 13:2)      μεθιστάνωfrom {{g3326}} and {{g2476}}; to transfer, i.e. carry away, depose or (figuratively) exchange, seduce
[μέθη] apparently a primary word; an intoxicant, i.e. (by implication) intoxication
[μεθερμηνεύω] from {{g3326}} and {{g2059}}; to explain over, i.e. translate
[μέγιστος] superlative of {{g3173}}; greatest or very great
[μεγιστᾶνες] plural from {{g3176}}; grandees
[μέγεθος] from {{g3173}}; magnitude (figuratively)
[μέγας] (including the prolonged forms, feminine μεγάλη, plural μεγάλοι, etc.; compare also {{g3176}}, {{g3187}}); big (literally or figuratively, in a very wide application)
[μεγαλωσύνη] from {{g3173}}; greatness, i.e. (figuratively) divinity (often God himself)
[μεγάλως] adverb from {{g3173}}; much
[μεγαλύνω] from {{g3173}}; to make (or declare) great, i.e. increase or (figuratively) extol

[μέλλω] a strengthened form of {{g3199}} (through the idea of expectation); to intend, i.e. be about to be, do, or suffer something (of persons or things, especially events; in the sense of purpose, duty, necessity, probability, possibility, or hesitation)
[Μελίτη] of uncertain origin; Melita, an island in the Mediterranean
[Μελχί] of Hebrew origin ({{h4428}} with pronominal suffix, my king); Melchi (i.e. Malki), the name of two Israelites
[μέλος] of uncertain affinity; a limb or part of the body
[μελετάω] from a presumed derivative of {{g3199}}; to take care of, i.e. (by implication) revolve in the mind
[Μελεᾶς] of uncertain origin; Meleas, an Israelite
[μελίσσιος] from {{g3192}}; relating to honey, i.e. bee (comb)
[μέλι] apparently a primary word; honey
[μέλω] a primary verb; to be of interest to, i.e. to concern (only third person singular present indicative used impersonally, it matters)
[Μελχισεδέκ] of Hebrew origin ({{h4442}}); Melchisedek (i.e. Malkitsedek), a patriarch
[μεγαλειότης] from {{g3167}}; superbness, i.e. glory or splendor
[μεγαλοπρεπής] from {{g3173}} and {{g4241}}; befitting greatness or magnificence (majestic)
[Ματταθά] probably a shortened form of {{g3161}} (compare {{h4992}}); Mattatha (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite
[Ματταθίας] of Hebrew origin ({{h4993}}); Mattathias (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite and a Christian
[μάχαιρα] probably feminine of a presumed derivative of {{g3163}}; a knife, i.e. dirk; figuratively, war, judicial punishment
[μάχη] from {{g3164}}; a battle, i.e. (figuratively) controversy
[μάχομαι] middle voice of an apparently primary verb; to war, i.e. (figuratively) to quarrel, dispute
[μέ] a shorter (and probably original) form of {{g1691}}; me
[μεγαλαυχέω] from a compound of {{g3173}} and αὐχέω (to boast; akin to {{g837}} and {{g2744}}); to talk big, i.e. be grandiloquent (arrogant, egotistic)
[μεγαλεῖος] from {{g3173}}; magnificent, i.e. (neuter, plural as noun) a conspicuous favor, or (subjectively) perfection
[μειζότερος] continued comparative of {{g3187}}; still larger (figuratively)
[μείζων] irregular comparative of {{g3173}}; larger (literally or figuratively, specially, in age)
[μεθύω] from another form of {{g3178}}; to drink to intoxication, i.e. get drunk
[μεῖζον] neuter of {{g3187}}; (adverbially) in greater degree
[μεθύσκω] a prolonged (transitive) form of {{g3184}}; to intoxicate
[μέθυσος] from {{g3184}}; tipsy, i.e. (as noun) a sot
[μεθοδεία] from a compound of {{g3326}} and {{g3593}} (compare "method"); travelling over, i.e. travesty (trickery)
[μεθόριος] from {{g3326}} and {{g3725}}; bounded alongside, i.e. contiguous (neuter plural as noun, frontier)
[μέλαν] neuter of {{g3189}} as noun; ink
[μέλας] apparently a primary word; black
[μαλακία] from {{g3120}}; softness, i.e. enervation (debility)
[μακροχρόνιος] from {{g3117}} and {{g5550}}; long-timed, i.e. long-lived
[μακροθυμία] from the same as {{g3116}}; longanimity, i.e. (objectively) forbearance or (subjectively) fortitude
[μακροθυμέω] from the same as {{g3116}}; to be long-spirited, i.e. (objectively) forbearing or (subjectively) patient
[μακρός] from {{g3372}}; long (in place (distant) or time (neuter plural))
[μακροθυμώς] adverb of a compound of {{g3117}} and {{g2372}}; with long (enduring) temper, i.e. leniently
[μάκελλον] of Latin origin (macellum); a butcher's stall, meat market or provision-shop
[Μακεδών] of uncertain derivation; a Macedon (Macedonian), i.e. inhabitant of Macedonia
[μακρόθεν] adverb from {{g3117}}; from a distance or afar
[μακράν] feminine accusative case singular of {{g3117}} ({{g3598}} being implied); at a distance (literally or figuratively)
[μακαρισμός] from {{g3106}}; beatification, i.e. attribution of good fortune
[Μακεδονία] from {{g3110}}; Macedonia, a region of Greece
[μακαρίζω] from {{g3107}}; to beatify, i.e. pronounce (or esteem) fortunate
[μακάριος] a prolonged form of the poetical μάκαρ (meaning the same); supremely blest; by extension, fortunate, well off
[Μαϊνάν] probably of Hebrew origin; Mainan, an Israelite
[μαίνομαι] middle voice from a primary μάω (to long for; through the idea of insensate craving); to rave as a "maniac"
[μαθήτρια] feminine from {{g3101}}; a female pupil
[Μαθουσάλα] of Hebrew origin ({{h4968}}); Mathusala (i.e. Methushelach), an antediluvian
[μαθητής] from {{g3129}}; a learner, i.e. pupil
